item.name: 10 Days in Africa
item.comment: Light filler and as a nice side effect you learn some African geography.

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: ZooSim meets Industrial Waste. Solid, a bit above the "Just Another Decent Euro" line, but it didn't leave me itching for more. But, I'll probably seek out playing this at least one more time.

item.name: The 3 Commandments
item.comment: A fun/silly deduction/induction game, which in an of itself is a rare thing. A little too long, but it's a party game, so people are usually having fun.

item.name: 6 Nimmt!
item.comment: This amazingly versatile game (2-10 players) can seem very random, but I'm a strong believer that there's actually a lot of control here. I'm a big fan of simultaneous play games, and this is a great game of psychology, hand management and risk taking.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Excellent civ building in half an hour. I'm finding it improving over consecutive plays.

item.name: Abenteuer im Wichtelwald
item.comment: Very good abstract strategy despite the fact that it has the trappings of a children's game.

item.name: Ace of Aces: Handy Rotary Series
item.comment: The system is exceptionally clever and the game isn't bad, but it's not anything special in terms of gameplay.

item.name: Ace of Aces: Powerhouse Series
item.comment: The system is exceptionally clever and the game isn't bad, but it's not anything special in terms of gameplay.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: Very good but it's easy to mess up the cash flow and can often lead to people being "out of it" for too long if they make what can seem like a minor error.

item.name: Ad Acta
item.comment: Interesting game of timing and stack management and I think the theme is clever.

item.name: Ad Liners
item.comment: Entertaining Apples-to-Apples-esque game with advertising slogans seemingly geared toward double entendres.

item.name: Adam & Eva
item.comment: Wonderful little "I cut, you choose" game with interesting hand management features along with good opportunities for bluffing and doublethink.

item.name: Adel Verpflichtet
item.comment: A classic, enjoyable, but it's a lot of double guessing.

item.name: Advanced Civilization
item.comment: Yes, it's a classic, but however good it is, it doesn't really justify it's play time. I only occasionally have the urge to play it again, and it's been years since I have.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: Ok, a lot of randomness, but a lot of fun. Dun-dun-dun-dun, dun-dun-dun..

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: A bit unforgiving and the scoring is a bit athematic, but the combined execution is very strong.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: Quite good, but feels a bit too much like an optimization puzzle rather than a game and way too long.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment: It tends to bog down a lot, but the game is better if played quickly.

item.name: Alexandros
item.comment: See my blog comments

item.name: Alibi
item.comment: Wow, look at that art.

item.name: Am Fuß des Kilimandscharo
item.comment: I was hoping there was more than just a really simple kids game here, but it appears that straightforward.

item.name: Das Amulett
item.comment: Outstanding two tiered auction game. If you're not careful, certain combos of powers can be unbalancing though.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: Outstanding and solid Knizia game of auctions and building. I got burnt out on it for a year or so, but it's retained staying power through that.

item.name: Andromeda
item.comment: I normally don't like area influence games, but the "probabilistic area influence" quality this has really feels rather fun and clever.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Neither my favorite dexterity game nor my favorite animal-stacking-themed game.

item.name: Antike
item.comment: Wonderful civilization development game. Extremely short turns allow for a feeling of constant engagement. The action selection mechanism is simple, elegant, clever and well-balanced.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: Perhaps one of the best party games ever. It has an extremely questionable level of skill involved, but is a huge amount of fun, and reasonably plays as few as 4 or as many as 10. This will continue to get pulled out for a long time. Often, this is a very amusing and light note on which to end a gaming session.

item.name: Arbos
item.comment: This is much better with adults if played on the "very hard" setting where the tree is extremely unstable.

item.name: Ark
item.comment: Beautiful artwork, interesting if not especially amazing game, and it's desperately in need of a reference card. Without it, it was common to get confused about the various card placement limitations. I'm also not so sure there's much plan ahead, but it's cute and small. (2 plays)

item.name: Around the World in 80 Days
item.comment: Very good. It combines some nice mechanics (card drafting, action selection, standard race game) with a clever twist (two different "race" goals) and is well executed. The clever part I especially like: each player is completing both to get back to London first (fewest number of game turns) as well as first (fewest number of "days" spent by playing cards). The game mechanics work out nicely such that these goals are somewhat in conflict; by delaying an extra game turn or two, you can likely finish the race in a fewer number of days. The way the win conditions are set up (must finish in under 80 days and must not finish last in game turns), it works rather well. This isn't a "big hit" kind of game, but it's fun. Especially if you enjoy unusual race games. It has a slightly similar feel to Marco Polo Expedition.

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: Outstanding mixture of strategic play and theme with the dexterity element being nice fun and not getting in the way of the game itself.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: I enjoyed this a lot but wow is it long.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: I like this a lot but substantially prefer it with the following variant, when playing with more than 2: Instead of connection causing a win, it allows the connector to draw 6 cards. This creates a more consistent overall feel for the game, to me.

item.name: Attila
item.comment: A underplayed stock/influence game with a much less business-like theme.

item.name: Attribute
item.comment: Plays best when the topics are specific to the group, eg, people at the table, common experiences, places, etc.

item.name: Authentic Demolition Derby
item.comment: Nice bits, cute idea, but it's simply not fun enough for how random/mundane it feels.

item.name: Balanx
item.comment: This is a nice tactical game with a clever use of it's tilting board.

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment: An outstanding addition to the Kosmos/Rio Grande 2-player line. I think it may be more luck based than it initially seems, but it's fun in any case.

item.name: Bambuti
item.comment: Underrated essentially abstract card game for two. A fair amount of luck, but some very interesting choices.

item.name: Barbarossa
item.comment: This is a great game, but it can be very sensitive to the right group and the right approach. The fact that it involves sculpting clay makes many treat it as a lighter game than it is. (not that it is THAT heavy)

item.name: Bargain Hunter
item.comment: This is probably my favorite of the large number of whist-variant card games out there. Trump changes on a trick-to-trick basis, the contents of the tricks won matters, and the theme makes at least as much sense as any trick-taking game theme does. Additionally, it plays with 3 very well in addition to working well with 4.

item.name: Basari
item.comment: Outstanding doublethink game.

item.name: Batik
item.comment: Clever and cute geometry/dexterity game that plays very quickly.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: This one is my favorite by Knizia. In the first two months of owning it, I played 10 times. In the second 2 months, another 10. Since then, it's tapered off some, but it still comes out on a regular basis. I'm sure it will hit 30 times by the end of the year (2002). This game has some of the same feel as Lost Cities, but with more depth and options. The tactics cards (and number 10 cards) are all that's been added over the original game

item.name: Battleball
item.comment: A pretty basic run-around-on-a-grid game with a nice mechanic for the slow pieces being better tacklers than the fast pieces. Nice minis.

item.name: Battlestations
item.comment: Almost a role playing game. In fact, it's might be over the line, but it's so close to self-adjudicating I'm happy to call it a board game. The best implementation of the whole "multi-scale" game thing I've ever played (ship-to-ship scale and crew scale)

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment: Oh, I so wanted to like this. After the first play, I was luke warm. One third of the way into the second play, I was hopeful, it looked like there might be some interesting and deeper hand management decisions than it originally seemed. Then, luck happened. I like luck in games. A lot. But, Beowulf has luck in the same (and only) place it has strategy and tactics: hand management. In addition to the luck of the draw, which is reasonably small and the usual factor in hand management games, it has the so called "risks", particularly during "major episodes" which are basically a magnified "luck of the draw". A good draw in a mid-episode risk is very beneficial. A bad draw in a mid-episode risk is very bad. If the luck were instead somewhere else, say in the selection of the order of the episodes, or in some other aspect of the game, it might not ruin it, but I think the potential variability of the swings of luck that so fundamentally and directly affect the core of the game eliminates too much of the impact of earlier decisions. At least I know I don't need another big box filling up shelf space.

item.name: The Best of Dragon Magazine Games
Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: This new Avalon Hill game is a lot of theme, which didn't really engage me, and only a very little game. It's a sort of neat idea, but not especially and the execution is mediocre. The components are nice, and there are some creative ideas, but I didn't see much I really thought was compelling.

item.name: The Big Idea
item.comment: This is a party game, and a good one, but I've seen people take it seriously, in which case it is no fun. As a party game, it's a blast.

item.name: Big Kini
item.comment: Good exploration game, but when it comes down to it, another player summed it up: "more of the same". It's got nice mechanisms, bits, and all that, though it lacks a feeling of tension.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Good minor variant on the full size game.

item.name: Blue Moon
item.comment: Grows on me each time I play it. Impressive amount of breadth and depth to the gameplay as well as very nice art and quick playing time.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: Initial impressions are very positive.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: An outstanding light trading game. It can be played in a very friendly way, or cutthroat, and is extremely fun, either way. The art is adorable and the theme is great. This is the ultimate game of trading for

item.name: Buy Low Sell High
item.comment: Motley Fool Edition. I love the basic market mechanic here.

item.name: BuyWord
item.comment: Can even be played semi-cooperatively and retain it's fun.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: Very cute, simple bluff, counter-bluff, special-powers, awesome-foam-handgun game. Unfortunately, it's outrageously expensive for what it is. Again, as a straight small package card game, I'd probably pick it up. As is, I can pass.

item.name: Caesar & Cleopatra
item.comment: Very solid flag influence game. The hidden/public cards mechanic feels less significant in play than it seems it should.

item.name: Café International
item.comment: Cute, light game of xenophobia.

item.name: Café International: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Very successful translation of a good game into a good card game.

item.name: Call my Bluff
item.comment: Outstanding. Most people would do a lot better at this game if they more reliably did the math. The endgame is especially interesting, whether to participate or watch, following elimination.

item.name: Camelot
item.comment: Great concept, not so great game.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: Another outstanding dice game. This is the ultimate game of brinkmanship. I vastly prefer the plastic red stop sign board to the

item.name: Candamir: The First Settlers
item.comment: Too slow and non-interactive. It feels like it could be good, but isn't quite there.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment: A couple of very clever mechanisms but can be overly hurt by bad play by others. I wish there were more strategic options but it is still fun.

item.name: Cape Horn
item.comment: Dry but fun, can have a high "screw your opponent" aspect.

item.name: Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game
item.comment: I really enjoyed this and felt it maintained the superhero feel without being catastrophically unbalanced (the usual problem).

item.name: Capitol
item.comment: Somehow uninteresting.

item.name: Capt'n Clever
item.comment: Fun simple game.

item.name: The Captain Is Dead
item.comment: Fun, tense, atmospheric co-op.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Carcassone is a clever and compelling spin on the free form tile laying genre. A variety of scoring options make for interesting strategic decisions that must be adapted as the board evolves. The mechanism of not allowing a

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: More of the same, and the art's not as good.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: Outstanding race and card management game.

item.name: Catch Phrase Junior
item.comment: Great version of the standard game, and the "junior" doesn't mean "lame".
item.conditiontext: Electronic Catchphrase Junior. New in box. offervalue:15

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: It's outstanding, but it's not quite as earth shaking as many have made it out to be. It's long, and it can have some downtime, which is not a good combination. It seems that usually it will be quite engaging with little downtime, but the length detracts. Above and beyond that, there's a nicely interlocking set of mechanisms, but nothing amazingly clever or revolutionary. It's a very well done resource management game with some novelty in the mechanisms. A definite buy, but it's not Puerto Rico. Even with experienced players, it's going to take 100-150 minutes, maybe more.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment: All of the good parts of Caylus, without all of the length.

item.name: Celebrities
item.comment: As party games go, this is pretty good, but very dependent on the group, even more so than most party games.

item.name: Celtica
item.comment: Beautiful artwork, but the randomness of the game so totally dwarfs the decision-making that the minimal decisons that remain are simple exercises in frustration. Oh well.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: Fun trading negotiation. The negotiation can be played seriously but amiably, while many other negotiation games tend to feel more cutthroat.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: I really wish this were better.

item.name: Ciao, Ciao...
item.comment: Interesting "pure" bluffing game. Doesn't hit the spot for many, but it's a clever distillation of a mechanic.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: Richly tactical and thematic game. The tactical feel is different in a good way from the more standard grid based tactical miniatures games.

item.name: Clifford the Big Red Dog Happy Birthday Game
Code 777
item.comment: As straight clue-driven deduction games go, about as good as it gets.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: I like it about as much as I can for a game I am catastrophically awful at.

item.name: Compatibility
item.comment: Fun "couples" game whether with actual couples or random pairings.

item.name: Cootie
item.comment: This is the rating as a kids game. As an adult game, it's not a game.

item.name: Cornerstone
item.comment: Cool concept, and maybe if I played without the dexterity/balance element I'd find it more satisfying.

item.name: Crocodile Pool Party
item.comment: How little can you throw in one of these boxes? Not as awful as many would lead you to believe, but it's one clever bit is that it's a abstract tactical game where your pieces are randomly valued. It works ok, but just ok.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: One of the richest dexterity/skill games out there. Personally, I prefer the slower boards rather than the waxed up frictionless surfaces some people prefer to play on.

item.name: Darter
item.comment: Fun two-player with just enough theme that it might not be called "abstract". A variety of interesting strategies are available.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Engaging, tactically interesting and fun dungeon crawl. The permutations of characters, abilities, treasures, scenarios and monsters are distinct feeling and rich in theme.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Diamonds Club
item.comment: Good interlocking system game, but a bit too decoupled from the theme. I don't think I'd often want to play this over numerous other "system games" (Puerto Rico, Goa, etc).

item.name: Dilbert: Corporate Shuffle
item.comment: Fun and the cartoons are cute. Not as much "staying power" for me as for some.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Really solid party game, and the art totally makes the game. I prefer more elaborate "hints", since I think it makes the game more fun, but it's fun however you play it.

item.name: A Dog's Life
item.comment: Ugh. Cute theme, but long, random, and dull.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
A compelling "sight reading" game where figuring out the strategy for the particular Kingdom (ie, set of cards) being used is a lot of the game. Plays fast and is very addictive. 100 plays later and it remains a winner.
Also, it plays shockingly well with my 6-year-old; the ability to play with essentially open hands helps, but the mechanics are not that complex when it comes down to it.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: A game with a lot of luck, but a really nice bit of gameplay which involves running from the erupting volcano. Certainly not the deepest game, but there are interesting tactical choices and even some strategic planning. Some of the turn timing seems to introduce more luck than is warranted though. Running from a volcano is entertaining.

item.name: Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde
item.comment: Amazingly clever, remarkably subtle, frustrating and fun.
item.conditiontext: Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde edition offervalue:12

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: A lot of fun and enough control to be interesting.

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: A bit dry and analysis heavy given that it seems like it should be really richly thematic, but it's got good decisions and interesting interactions.

item.name: Easy Come, Easy Go
item.comment: Good. It's an exceedingly simple dice game with a great deal of luck and many of the decisions are fairly obvious. That said, it's quite fun and very quick. There is a bit more to the game than it seems at first, but that's not to say there are great depths to be plumbed here. Deduct 4 points from the rating if you don't like light, luck-heavy dice games.

item.name: Edel, Stein & Reich
item.comment: Basari is much better

item.name: Egizia
item.comment: At some level, this is Just Another Good Euro. Better than decent, and interesting choices and mechanics, but not amazing. Definitely good though.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: Much better than Candamir. It doesn't feel that innovative, but it is a well crafted combination of familiar mechanics along with a few clever bits. If you like Catan-style development games, this is definitely worth a try.

item.name: Electronic Catchphrase
item.comment: A great beeping filler game.

item.name: Elefantenparade
item.comment: A very nice, simple, but sometimes subtle game.

item.name: Elementals
item.comment: Simple slap-jack style speed recognition games with attractively illustrated little elemental men. If you like that sort of thing, it's pretty good.

item.name: Elements
item.comment: Works substantially better with 3 than with 5 players. The random card draws introduces a little randomness yet the fewer players gives the players more control. With 3, it's a good game. With 5 it's just ok.

item.name: Emira
item.comment: Interesting dynamics and combinations of mechanics. I wish it felt a little quicker paced, but that could just be a learning curve issue. Feels well balanced and with an impressive set of strategic options.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: Decent, but nothing deeply special to be offered here.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Expedition
item.comment: I find the art for Wildlife Adventure more appealing and clearer for gameplay and the games are so close, I'll play that over Expedtion...

item.name: Fact or Crap
item.comment: One of the worse "trivia" games I've ever played. Dumb/bad/uninteresting questions, stupid gameplay. Avoid.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment: This is really entertaining and a novel feeling puzzle game, and the machine names and art are the icing on the cake.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: Interesting. I actually think it's fairly good, but I have a nagging feeling there is less subtlety to the game than it seems. The art is cute and the odd "Engrish" isn't too distracting, though it seems common that players have a hard time with the fact that "Close All {1 fairies}" actually means "All players turn 1 fairy card face down". In any case, this also wins some points for cleverness by using a Magic: The Gathering style draft for card selection as well as a somewhat novel card flipping mechanism.

item.name: Familienbande
item.comment:
Seriously underrated game. This is fun game of hidden goals and gradual manipulation.
I need to try it with a house rule where you can draw from a choice of 3 face-up cards instead of just drawing from the deck. It seems like it would eliminate some of the occasionally substantial luck and not slow things down much.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
Fettnapf
item.comment: Enh. Cute mechanic and nice integration of cardplay and memory, but in the end I'm not sure I believe your decisions (what card to play) really makes much of a difference.

item.name: Fiese Freunde Fette Feten
item.comment: Great theme, great gameplay, great art. I love the multi-dimensional optimization and how that interplays with the auctions as well as the whole timing game.

item.name: Figaro
item.comment: A little to chaotic without being interesting at the same time.

item.name: Fiji
item.comment: Fun, brain-twisting decisions with a generous share of double- and triple-guessing. It's light, quick and chaotic enough to make those qualities fun and engaging. With 3, it's tactical and interesting double-guessing. With 4 or 5, it's more chaotic, but still fun.

item.name: Finstere Flure
item.comment: Outstanding game.

item.name: Fjords
item.comment: Cute little 2-phase game where each phase has a distinct, but coordinated feel.

item.name: Flickwerk
item.comment: Engaging puzzle-solving, though people's abilities at this seem often quite assymetric leading to substantial blowouts.

item.name: Flinke Pinke
item.comment: A great filler, with interesting decisions, second-guessing, and opportunities for different styles of play, and quick to teach.

item.name: Floriado
item.comment: I finally got around to playing this game from Cwali which they were giving away free with any purchase at Essen. It exceeded my expectation for a free game. It's a quick little game of set collecting with several constraints. Very nice.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: Too slow, or too fast. Too chaotic, or too static. Not a fun experience.

item.name: Focus
item.comment: Nice abstract with interesting options.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Another quick one, but a really great one. I'm a big fan of both auction mechanics and blind bidding, so it's an unsurprising winner. It's also simple enough to play with non-gamers but has a lot of clever tactics and the art is beautiful.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: Very solid Pandemic-lite. This game has grown on me with repeated plays and is very very good with young kids (mine: 6&4) since it's coop and open hands. The narrative arc of the game is fun and sufficiently variable that I'm really glad to have this game.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: This was good. Not amazing, not revolutionary, but quick, a nice refinement of the Too Many Cooks mechanic and fun. It's a shame it's so overproduced. If Amigo (or someone else) comes out with a version in the small "standard" card box size, I'll definitely pick it up. Otherwise, I'll hold on to that shelf space and play someone else's copy.
item.wishlistcomment: Only want the Amigo or other small edition, if it exists.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment:
Fun and clever with an engaging theme and mechanics, but the chaos and dissonance of the two phases is just too annoying. There could be something truly great here, but it's not.
Space Alert (same designer) is much more of what I wish this game was.

item.name: Gheos
item.comment: It seems to have more depth and layers than it seemed from reading the rules.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: Fun thematic cooperative game where the easiest setting isn't too easy, but is pretty achievable.

item.name: Giants
item.comment: Nice and thematic with seemingly multiple paths to victory, but feels a bit like "more of the same".

item.name: Gipsy King
item.comment: A bit mundane, but not bad. It's all about timing.

item.name: Give Me the Brain!
item.comment: With the right crowd at the righ time, can be silly fun. Otherwise, bland play-cards-that-tell-you-what-to-do game.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: Not awful, but I'd play San Juan over this any day, and they have a similar sort of architecture.

item.name: Go Away Monster!
item.comment: An outstanding game for 2- and 3-year-olds. With adults the rating would be a 2, but why would you play it with adults?

item.name: Goa
item.comment: A great game of interlocking systems with many many paths to victory.

item.name: Gossip
item.comment: Hard to rate. It's clever, thematic, and very odd. I'm not likely to play it very often, but I certainly wouldn't call it "average".

item.name: Guatemala Café
item.comment: Enh, just didn't do it for me.

item.name: guten und die bï¿½sen Geister, Die
item.comment: Fun tactical bluffing, hedging and second-guessing game that plays in almost no time at all.

item.name: Hacienda
item.comment: This just felt to mundane.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: Monotonous, but probably deserves another try.

item.name: Haste Worte?
item.comment: I want a version with English cards and _well designed_ categories.

item.name: Havana
item.comment: Just not that much here.

item.name: Havoc: The Hundred Years War
item.comment: Disappointing. Very luck of the draw/draft driven and even when I felt I had control I didn't enjoy it much. It has some serious similarities to Taj Mahal, but I think I'd rather play that anyday. It might be better with fewer (we played with 6).

item.name: The Heavens of Olympus
item.comment: Interesting role selection/area influence, but a bit too area-influency for me. If that's really your thing, it may just hit the spot.

item.name: Heroes of Graxia
item.comment: Very appealing, and good mechanics, but in actual play it has some problems with length and the PvP is a bit troublesome. Probably worth another try at some point, but it's just not quite there.

item.name: Heroica: Fortaan
item.comment:
(As played with little kids)
Great dungeon crawl. Not a lot of decisions, but some, and captures the feel of a dungeon crawl well.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment: Best minatures game I've played in both rules and components.

item.name: Hex
item.comment: A classic connection game. Fun & quick.

item.name: Hexagony
item.comment: Most of the things I don't like (fiddliness, rules style/complexity) about wargames without any of the things I do like (theme, feeling of simulation, narrative engagement).
item.conditiontext: Played once. Bin'Fa edition in tube.

item.name: Hick Hack in Gackelwack
item.comment: Effective and entertaining filler playable with gamers and non-gamers alike. Best with 6.

item.name: High Tail It!
item.comment: Very good tactical abstract.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: A little too dry.

item.name: Igel Ärgern
item.comment: One of the best fillers out there. It offers just the right amount of luck, choices, and take-that opportunities.

item.name: Im Märchenwald
item.comment: Outstanding cooperative children's memory game. As an adult strategy game would rate a 1 or 2, but that's not what it is.

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: A solid Alea offering, not dissimilar from Notre Dame, but different enough to stand on its own.

item.name: Incan Gold
item.comment: It's not "Can't Stop", but it's a fun quick game of brinkmanship that supports a lot of players well.

item.name: Industrial Waste
item.comment: Great game, very heavy on strategy, very light on tactics.

item.name: It's Mine!
item.comment:
AKA "Slap Ra". Excellent little filler that plays best when the dealer really "talks up" the "offer".
My kids started especially loving it when they were 6 & 4.

item.name: Jumbo & Co
item.comment: Multi-player, card-counting assisted "rock, paper, scissors". Enh. Not really interesting.

item.name: Kahuna
item.comment: Too easy to fall behind and "get stuck" and when that happens it's no fun for the victor or the victim. Among players who can consistently avoid this, it'd be much better.

item.name: Kaigan
item.comment: Just Another Decent Euro. Maybe even "soulless" :) The core mechanic is good, but the total assembly doesn't live up to the promise.

item.name: King Arthur: The Card Game
item.comment: Nice card game, but not a lot of depth. Decent as filler.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: Take-that kind of filler that I like more than most take-that games.

item.name: King's Breakfast
item.comment: Fun, light food-themed game that's easy to introduce people to and remains interesting upon repeated play.

item.name: Knack den Code-X
item.comment: Not actually a lot of game here, sadly.

item.name: Knockabout
item.comment: Low luck (despite dice). Interesting tactical options, involving play and a lot of replay value.

item.name: König Salomons Schatzkammer
item.comment: Very cool, but in the end I didn't actually like it that much. Very nice components, though the levels of the stacks are often a bit difficult to read, which is crucial to gameplay. There's also a fair amount of downtime with minimal if any ability to plan ahead. I feel like something's there, but I'm not quite sure.

item.name: Kuller Spass
item.comment: Cool little fast kids dexterity game, with a nice handicapping variant. (Rated as a kids game)

item.name: Launch Across
item.comment: Lots of fun to play a bunch, once.

item.name: Leapfrog
item.comment: A light little "race" game. It's not really a race game in the traditional sense, more of a second-guessing/simultaneous-selection game. Light, cute fun. It plays quite fast as well.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Light Speed
item.comment: Very clever/novel speed game, unlike the standard "play cards quickly" game. I can only recommend this with two players, as then the scoring and play take about equal time. With more than two, the scoring takes far longer than the gameplay and that's just annoying.

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
Loopin' Louie
item.comment: This is probably the best dexterity game ever. Louie is a little motorized plane which circles around trying to knock chickens off your barn, but if you hit your paddle at the right time, you can send him looping toward your opponents. Amazingly fun, and the description doesn't do it justice.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment:
Evocative, tense, and engaging. After years of playing this it remains among my all time favorites. Plays wonderfully with or without expansions, but I enjoy it especially with both expansions and all optional rules in use. Playing Sauron is great fun, as is playing against a player-Sauron.
One of the most intense and positive gaming experiences on a consistent basis.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Lost Cities
item.comment: Reiner Knizia is one of my favorite designers, and this is one of the many reasons. This is a reasonably quick, but deep 2-player card game that's not too much of a brain burner. Lots of interesting strategic and tactical decisions, and the endgame timing is subtle and powerful. Plus, the card art is beautiful.

item.name: Lost Valley
item.comment: Way too unengaging given how mechanical it is. Nice bits, it's a shame the game is so plain.

item.name: Ludoviel
item.comment: Clever game about games, takes the right set of players.

item.name: Luna
item.comment: Just Another Decent Euro. Nice bits and interesting mechanics, but I found the degree to which I never had enough opportunity to do all my actions more frustrating than pleasantly tense.

item.name: Lunatix Loop
item.comment: Limited edition early Matt Leacock (of Pandemic fame) game. Played once or twice.
item.conditiontext: Played once, essentially new condition. Signed by the designer. offervalue:80

item.name: Ma Ni Ki
item.comment: See my blog comments

item.name: Mage Wars Arena
item.comment:
Wow, this game is really something. It's a CCG-style game with a substantial tactical combat element that attempts to emulate the feel of dueling mages. I think it succeeds.
It is intimidating, in the sense that each player has a "spellbook" (literally a binder full of cards) with dozens of unique cards in at least 6 or 7 major varieties, any one of which often has special power text, and most of which have various special modifier words, which come from a codex of dozens of descriptors. And, each turn you have access to a huge portion of your spellbook, so the learning curve is a bit steep. Both of us playing have played many games of this style/complexity before, and in actual play, the complexity wasn't bad, but it's definitely a bit overwhelming.
The game is fun, tactically interesting, and ended up quite even with some interesting exchanges and interactions. In the end, I think this is a "lifestyle game" though. The complexity is more of the magnitude of a game like Dungeons & Dragons or Magic: The Gathering, and it seems like it would shine with both players being dedicated to and familiar with the game. I could see this game potentially being very rewarding if one were to make a bit of a "lifestyle" of it. That said, it was fun even as a one off.
In the end, it's thematic, well-balanced, and extremely complex in a compelling way.

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Mamma Mia!
item.comment: This is probably one of the best games incorporating a substantial memory component. Memory games, as a class, are often children's games because they give kids a chance against adults. The memory aspect here has that effect to some degree, but the cardplay and sheer volume of cards make it not the dominating aspect of the game. Lots of quick fun, especially with pre-teen aged kids.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: One of the better betting games out there, along with Royal Turf.

item.name: Marvel Heroes
item.comment: A bit too long, and to really immerse oneself in the theme, which is much of the appeal, it would take even longer. The rating may go up with a little more experience though.

item.name: Masons
item.comment: Good decisions, engaging play, not earthshaking, but very good.

item.name: Mäuse-Rallye
item.comment: An entertaining flicking game, typically used as filler. I bet it plays well with kids, too ;-)

item.name: Medici
item.comment: One of the best auction games, ever. The auctions combining money and "slots on the ship" interact in compelling and deep ways.

item.name: Medici vs Strozzi
item.comment: Interesting and engaging, if a bit dry.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Not so much better than Battle Cry.

item.name: Mesopotamia
item.comment: Nice exploration/development/pick-up-and-deliver game. The actions cards are a bit more variable in power level than I'd like ideally (ie, some are very good, some are quite poor) but it's still nice. The exploration element here is very light, but I like it. Plays reasonably quickly too.

item.name: Midnight Party
item.comment:
Good fun kids push-your-luck game, but I think Viva Topo is better.
(rated as a kids game)

item.name: Mississippi
item.comment: See my blog comments

item.name: Mole Hill
item.comment: A great asymmetric game. It's got an entertaining learning curve, because of some non-obvious farmer strategies.

item.name: Monkey Madness
item.comment: Outstanding game 2- and 3-year-olds that, while lacking choices, is entertaining for even older kids.

item.name: Monsterjagd
item.comment: Cute twitch game. Silly, light, quick.

item.name: Montanara
item.comment: Not much game here and not that interesting.

item.name: Monza
item.comment: Cute/fun kids' game I can play with my almost-3-year-old. Rating is for that audience. With adults, it's still probably a 5 or 6.

item.name: Mü & More
item.comment: I actually really really like this game at some level, but I find myself uninterested in "making the commitment" of playing enough to learn it well to really get the most out of it. When it comes down to it, if I'm going to play a trick taking game, there's any number of others I'll go to first (Schnaeppchen Jagd, Foppen, notably).

item.name: Mystery Garden
item.comment: One of my 4-year-old's favorites. Essentially a formalized version of 20 questions, but with only 15 questions.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment: Interesting, but not deeply compelling and the nature and magnitude of some of the point swings in the end game seem to make this less interesting. I'll try it again, but don't need to buy it.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: Simple, fun war-gamish game. It's got lots of little rules, but the interactions of them is the whole point of the game. We started out playing slowly, and it was ok. We were running out of time so had to play very fast, and it's much better that way.

item.name: The Newlywed Game
item.comment: Fun under the right circumstances.

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: Quick, entertaining, and fun family game that's got more to it than many seem to give it credit.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Clever, fun with a reasonable variety of strategies to explore.

item.name: Oh, Pharaoh!
item.comment: A bit bland, and too much "take that" for my taste. A little long for what it is.

item.name: Old Town
item.comment: Clever pseudo-deduction. I'm not sure how much real control there is, but it's neat.

item.name: Oriente
item.comment: Badly written rules didn't help here.

item.name: Pack & Stack
item.comment: Fun, light geometry game. We played with a variant for 5: Winner of the previous round flips two trucks. Also, none of this random draw for the last player.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
Pente
item.comment: Also known as Ninuki (or Ninuki-Renju) this is an extremely satisfying and quick two player abstract.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: I really want to like this, but I find it far to mechanical without feeling like the choices are compelling and interesting rather than annoying.

item.name: Pico 2
item.comment: One of the deepest games you can player in under 5 minutes.

item.name: Pocket Battles: Elves vs. Orcs
item.comment: Seems like a decent minis combat game. Not really my thing.

item.name: Poisson d'Avril
item.comment: Gets pulled out once a year and generally isn't as entertaining as most people seem to think. Actually, sort of annoying.

item.name: Pompeji
item.comment: A good little filler "tile laying" game. The card art leaves something to be desired, but not bad.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment: At least it's fast.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: For a game that _sounds_ really mundane and mechanical from reading the rules, it's really far from mundane, and the mechanics are just the right amount of different things to have to keep track of to keep this as an all-time classic.

item.name: Der Prestel Kunstmarkt
item.comment: Fun little requirements-matching game. The pieces are pretty, but sacrifice convenience of play for that beauty. The rating would be higher, but I feel like it is likely to lose somewhat on repeat play.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: One of the all time classics. When it comes down to it, the constraints of this game (you win 7 auctions and take 14 actions. Period.) make it remarkably analyzable, without usually falling to bad analysis-paralysis, largely because there remain multiple effective paths to winning.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: There is something very appealing about this, and it's a well constructed set of rules, etc. etc, but it just ends up feeling to dry/mechanical to excel.

item.name: Il Principe
item.comment: Not for me, but I can see others enjoying it. The way the mechanics combine feels "clunky" somehow.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Surprisingly reasonable to teach to newcomers and it deserves all the praise it gets.

item.name: Puerto Rico: Expansion I – New Buildings
item.comment: Fun variation on the usual buildings.

item.name: Quadtria
item.comment: A sort of unremarkable abstract.

item.name: Quietville
item.comment: Standard Schacht. Good, interesting mechanisms, somewhat interesting play, no "spark".

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Fun, and easily handicapped (different number of fences) with kids.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: Very Ingenious-like, but different and clever enough to be fun on its own.

item.name: R.U.M.B.L.
item.comment: This sounds right up my alley, and I like much of Greg's other stuff, but this just was too far over the line of chaotic without control. That said, the mechanics are clever and interesting, and the score is likely to go up if I ever play again, but not sure by how much.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: This may be my favorite auction game. Rather different from a traditional auction game, it borrows aspects from several other games as well as a few novel bits of its own. The discrete nature of the bidding tiles, the wide range of scoring options, the simple but important strategic decision of when to call an auction and the reasonably playing time combine to make this an outstanding game.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
I've been "seriously" gaming for 10+ years, played nearly 1000 different titles and for the first time, without equivocation, I can answer the "What's your favorite game?" question. An [b]outstanding[/b] game in the style of San Juan (actually it's the other way around). The art is exceptional. The game is fast, but full of compelling tactical options, interesting combinations, engaging thematic elements and numerous strategies to pursue. In the less than a year since it's been out, it's become my 3rd most played game ever and I have no doubt it will be the most played before long.
EDIT/UPDATE: >5 years after I wrote this comment and all of the above remains true, and it's become my most played game. I mostly only play with the first two expansions, without takeover rules, but enjoy all of the expansions.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
Reef Encounter
item.comment: Failed to grab me. I don't feel like the mechanics hang well together, it has just a bit too much take-that-ism and is prone to slow play. Oh, and I find it annoying for reasons I can't quite put my finger on.

item.name: Ricochet Robot
item.comment: Some people really like this sort of puzzle solving game, and others don't. I tend to enjoy them. If you don't like puzzles, this may not be right for you, but if you do, it's a great set up for a puzzle, and the simple

item.name: Robin Hood
item.comment: Clever little physical/memory mechanism that drives movement. Very much a kids game.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: RoboRally, despite being an American game, was the game that really turned me on to Designer/German games. Despite being a long, and to many people, complicated game, I played a lot of this, and was fortunate enough to get all the expansions before they, and the main game, went out of print in the US. I highly recommend this game, especially to those with a technical bent. I haven't played it much recently (4 times in the past 2 years), but I expect to occasionally play it for many years to come.
item.conditiontext: Want new Avalon Hill edition wantvalue:25

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: A very good execution of a dice-civ game. Exactly what it sounds like.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: Interesting, and I haven't had the chanc e to explore all the interactions. Don't get to play it enough.

item.name: Rotundo
item.comment: Odd Adlung game about collecing spherical objects. Not awful, but nothing too inspired and definitely an odd theme. I bet if you translated it to English and named it "Balls!", you'd get sales on the name alone. Gameplay has an interesting bit or two but ends up feeling mundane.

item.name: Rum & Pirates
item.comment: We didn't even play all the rounds. It could be worse, but I doubt I will be convinced to try it again.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment:
Pueblo-like game of building using 3 dimensional blocks. It scores differently, in fact nearly opposite and the gameplay is somewhat different (your pieces must touch your other pieces). Overall, its good, perhaps has good or better then Pueblo. Plus, it comes with a nice "Lazy Susan" style board which Pueblo would benefit from.
Plays very well with younger kids (mine are 6&4).

item.name: Rutschpartie mit Winnie the Pooh
item.comment: Rating as a kids game.

item.name: Sag's mit Symbolen
item.comment: We played this, thinking it would be a nice light not-quite-party-game. Oops. It's an odd little pseudo-deduction/clue-giving game. It's actually got some rather interesting and difficult decisions. It'd be nice to have it in English, but using a translation sheet wasn't bad.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Outstanding game that's fun to try out the many different strategies and rewards rapid adaption (to both card draw and other players' behavior). Scales well from 2 to 4 players. Lowered rating to a 9 just because Race so completely trumps it.

item.name: Schwarzarbeit
item.comment: Unusually clever deduction game which isn't just a straight note-taking logic-puzzle endeavor. I like a deduction game that rewards informed guessing.

item.name: SET
item.comment: This is a very clever little filler game, which my wife is upsettingly good at. It can be a bit of a brain burner, but it's engaging and quick. It is one of the few

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Gorgeous and fun but the gameplay itself is pretty dull and abstract. I substantially prefer the LOTR cooperative game (with or without Sauron).

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: The Aardman-esque sheep are really cute, but when it comes down to it, it's an abstract puzzle game and really not that interesting of one. Plus, it seems to have some kingmaker issues which is even more annoying in a puzzle game.

item.name: Sneaks & Snitches
item.comment: I don't think I'd ever play this over Hick Hack in Gacklewack.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Wow. Absolutely amazing combination of 3 things I like a lot (cooperative, programmed movement, rich sci-fi theme) and one thing I like fine (realtime) makes for an exceptional and novel game. I can't get it out of my head.

item.name: Space Beans
item.comment: Best if played _fast_. Slow play breaks this game down a lot, since it becomes too easy to memorize everything that's going on.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: Very entertaining and engaging. "Balancing" the timer split among players is important though.

item.name: Speed
item.comment: I'd picked this up at Essen in 2000, and hadn't played it much. Then, for some reason, I picked it up again in summer of 2001, and haven't stopped playing it. For a game that plays in under 60 seconds, it is surprisingly satisfying, and lends itself well to the

item.name: Spinball
item.comment: One of the top few dexterity games ever.

item.name: Spot it!
item.comment: Any game where deconstructing the design leads to an understanding of combinatoral block design is a good first step. But, not required to play, and it's fun.

item.name: Starship Merchants
item.comment:
This is a really well crafted game, with an interesting theme, witha core set of mechanics that I just don't like that much.
It's a pick-up-and-deliver game with spaceship purchasing, obsolescence technologies, pilots, mining claims, etc, but at it's core it's an economic pick-up-and-deliver game like some railroad games, and even though I like the idea of that kind of game, I don't find myself that fond of them in actual play.
There do seem to be a variety of reasonable strategies and cool options, and interesting tempo aspects to the game. The total scale of the end game compared to the cost of ships makes the game feel even more about precision timing, and less about the strategies chosen. This is, again, a less favored style of game for me.

item.name: Strange Synergy
item.comment: It's random, chaotic, horribly unbalanced, often sort of tedious, and in some cases actually downright broken, but for some reason I like it a lot.

item.name: Streetcar
item.comment: A nice combination of route/connection mechanics with hidden goals.

item.name: Strozzi
item.comment: Rating may well go up. Seems like a clever intersection of Medici and Ra.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: Nice mechanics that combine together to form a tedious mechanical wargamey experience. Not my thing at all.

item.name: Sudoku Challenge
item.comment: Nothing amazing, but a decent conversion of Sudoku into a game that's better than parallel puzzle solving.

item.name: Sushi Express
item.comment: Super random, super light, quite fast, not bad.

item.name: Tabula Rasa
item.comment: A solid flag-influence game, fun and quick.

item.name: Take it Easy!
item.comment: Supports from 2-10 players, plays quick, and involves psychedelic colors. This is a multiplayer solitaire game that's a lot of fun, though there are variants that add a small amount of player interaction that are fun as well. It ends up feeling like

item.name: Tanz der Hornochsen!
item.comment: A boardgame (barely) version of "6 nimmt!" It's fun and it's got some good twists above and beyond the basic gameplay, which closely resembles 6 nimmt!, but in the end, I'm not sure it adds that much. What does seem possible is that this may do better with fewer players while the original prefers more like 5 or 6 players. The tiles are a bit annoying compared to cards and the whole aspect of everyone having the option to buy cards before each turn really messes up the pacing. Fun, but I may mostly stick to 6 nimmt!, and I'm usually a big fan of novelty.4

item.name: Techno Witches
item.comment: Surprisingly engaging pre-programmed measured movement race game. The components are nice and the mechanics are clever. My only wish is they had components for more than 4 players. It cries out for a Harry Potter brand licensing.

item.name: Terra Prime
item.comment: A bit harsh and not that fun. And the production values are a little embarassing.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Mechanically captures the feel of research/execution, making the theme work very well. It's only weakness is the tile draw is a bit too random, but it's very close to being "just right".

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Excellent and approachable. Multiple paths to victory though "longest camel chain" seems often underestimated.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: Blah.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Quite good, but I don't find it as revolutionary as many.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: I like it a bit better than the "US" version.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: A good tight 2/3 player map, but the rules tweaks seem just distracting/confusing compared to the other versions.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: This is a really nice variant route set.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: An outstanding dice game, better with fewer rather than more, since it plays more quickly.

item.name: Tongiaki
item.comment: It's chaotic and fun, and the right length (short) for that combination. Plus, lots of opportunity for clever plays and amusing interactions.

item.name: Toppo
item.comment: Fun speed pattern recognition in the mold of Set or Oraklos.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: I find it tedious, dry and mundane.

item.name: Tower of Babel
item.comment: I think I've enjoyed this more with fewer than with more, but I haven't played it enough to be sure.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: Despite many complaints that the strategic depth of this maxes out quickly, I find this has had a great deal of longevity and remains fun despite the relative ease with which many people seem to think they can find the optimal strategy.

item.name: Traumfabrik
item.comment: This is an outstanding Knizia auction/set-collecting game, worthy of inclusion of the oft-cited Knizia auction

item.name: Triology
item.comment: Exceedingly brain burningly intense and not much fun for all that effort. Drags awfully as a result. Play Set instead.

item.name: Turbo
item.comment: Cute speed game.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: Cool bits, fun concept, but for it's length, there's others I'll much more eagerly play.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
When I first saw and read about this, I immediately assumed I wouldn't like it. It's a long, historical area influence game, all strikes against a game in my book. So, I didn't play it.
Nearly a year later, everyone continues to rave about it, and it seems to have nearly universal appeal, so I decided to give it a try. I read more about it and become more inclined to think I'd like it. It's a card-driven system, similar to We The People which is a rare long, historical game I LIKE. I was really looking forward to trying it.
Finally, I tried it. It was interesting, and I didn't dislike the experience, but mostly all of my initial concerns turned out to be true. It just doesn't do it for me. Under the right circumstances I could be convinced to play it again, and I understand why some people like it, but I can't say I understand the overwhelming positivity toward this game.

item.name: Twixt
item.comment: One of the great connection games, and works with very young kids, at least mechanically.

item.name: Typo
item.comment: See my blog comments

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: Cute speed puzzle solving, surprising it hasn't been done before.

item.name: ...und tschüss!
item.comment: Good game, but I'd rather play 6 nimmt! I find this just too short and luck driven.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: Never got much out of it.

item.name: Urland
item.comment: Good game, but too long for what it is. The turn timing is interesting.

item.name: Vabanque
item.comment: I really want to like this, and at some level I think I do, but every time I play it everyone else despises it so, I doubt I'll bring it out often because I don't want to inflict this on others.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment: A very good pick-up-and-deliver game, and those aren't usually my thing.

item.name: Victory & Honor
item.comment: Very good trick taking game. In fact, one of the best new ones I've played in a while. The twist in this one is that you play three tricks ("left", "center" and "right") at a time. If you play a card to your "left" trick, your left hand opponent must play the next card. It's a little complicated to wrap a strategy around at first, but it's a lot of fun and very interesting. Clever.

item.name: Virus & Co
item.comment: Too much rules for too little game.

item.name: VisualEyes
item.comment: It's a cute mechanic that works surprisingly well. There's enough combinations that it doesn't get stale quickly.

item.name: Viva Topo!
item.comment: Rated as a kids game. An excellent little push-your-luck race game, where a variety of strategies are viable, depending how the dice fall.

item.name: Walk the Dogs
item.comment: With kids, the rating would be much higher.

item.name: Wallenstein (first edition)
item.comment: Not bad, but not that impressive.

item.name: WFF 'N PROOF
item.comment: If you think doing formal logic proofs are fun, you'd probably have more fun sitting down and doing some proofs than playing this game. If you don't think it sounds like fun, you certainly won't like it.

item.name: Who Lives Where?
item.comment: Rated as a kids game.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: Perhaps the best betting game out there. Go Nougat!

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: Substantially better than average trivia game, with well structured questions, and it's fun.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: Rummy games are not my thing, but other than Zirkus Flohcati, this is about as good as they get.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: It felt like it was too short to utilize a reasonable fraction of the game elements, but too long for the amount of luck and nature of the game

item.name: Zauberschwert & Drachenei
item.comment: Well designed, simple fantasy themed game, but not that engaging when it comes down to it.

item.name: Zicke Zacke Hühnerkacke
item.comment: One of the better straightforward memory games out there.

item.name: Zig-Zag
item.comment: Cute little filler speed game. With my 4-year-old we play a variant: Kids can keep going after an adult calls stop. It works very well.

item.name: Zing!
item.comment: I think I'd mostly rather play Spades, but it's somewhat novel.

item.name: Zirkus Flohcati
item.comment: I only recently discovered this game, and it is definitely in the filler category, but it's really good filler. It's a good combination of jeapordy (flip one more card, or not?) game and set collecting. The multiple paths to victory (despite claims I've read elsewhere, the non-Gala players do win sometimes) makes it a quite filling little filler.
